{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Boletus chrysenteron LC0072.jpg | image_width=234px | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Boletales]] | familia = [[Boletaceae]] | genus = ''[[Xerocomellus]]'' | species = '''''X. chrysenteron''''' | binomial = ''Xerocomellus chrysenteron'' | binomial_authority = ([[Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard|Bull.]]) Šutara (2008) | synonyms = ''Boletus chrysenteron'' Bull. (1789)
''Xerocomus chrysenteron'' [[Lucien Quélet|Quél.]]
''Boletus pascuus'' ([[Christian Hendrik Persoon|Pers.]]) [[Julius Vincenz von Krombholz|Krombh.]] }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Xerocomellus chrysenteron'' | capShape = convex | hymeniumType = pores | stipeCharacter = bare | sporePrintColor = olive-brown | howEdible = edible }} {{stack end}} '''''Xerocomellus chrysenteron''''', formerly known as '''''Boletus chrysenteron''''' or '''''Xerocomus chrysenteron''''', is a small, [[edible mushroom|edible]], wild [[mushroom]] in the family [[Boletaceae]]. These mushrooms have tubes and pores instead of [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] beneath their [[Pileus (mycology)|caps]]. It is commonly known as the '''red cracking bolete'''.{{cite book | author = Roger Phillips | year = 2006 | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 0-330-44237-6}} ==Taxonomy== This mushroom was first described and named as ''Boletus communis'' in 1789 by the eminent French botanist [[Jean Baptiste Francois Pierre Bulliard]]. Two years later in 1791 it was given the [[botanical name|specific epithet]] ''chrysenteron'' by the same author. The species name coming from the [[Ancient Greek]] words ''khrysos'' "gold" and ''enteron'' "innards".{{cite book |author=Nilson S, Persson O. |year=1977 |title=Fungi of Northern Europe 1: Larger Fungi (Excluding Gill-Fungi) |publisher=Penguin |location=Harmondsworth, UK |isbn=0-14-063005-8 |pages=106–07}} Almost one hundred years later in 1888 [[Lucien Quelet]] placed it in the new genus ''Xerocomus'', and retained the ''chrysenteron'' epithet. This binomial was generally accepted for almost another hundred years, until 1985 when [[Marcel Bon]] decided to resurrect the former specific epithet ''communis'', which resulted in the binomial ''Xerocomus communis''. It now resides back in the genus ''Boletus'', and sports its 1791 binomial, and authority once again, and is currently known as [https://web.archive.org/web/20110720010621/http://www.basidiochecklist.info/DisplayResults.asp?intGBNum=13558 ''Boletus chrysenteron'' Bull.] Recent phylogenetic analysis supports the placement of ''X. chrysenteron'' as the [[type species]] of the new genus ''[[Xerocomellus]]'', described by Šutara in 2008.{{cite journal |author=Šutara J. |title=''Xerocomus'' s. l. in the light of the present state of knowledge |journal=Czech Mycology |year=2008 |volume=60 |issue=1 |pages=29–62 |url=http://web.natur.cuni.cz/cvsm/CM60104F.pdf}} ==Description== [[File:Red Cracking Bolete (Boletus chrysenteron) spore print.JPG|thumb|left|[[Spore print]]]] [[File:Boletus chrysenteron (Red Cracking Bolete).JPG|thumb|right]] Young specimens of ''X. chrysenteron'' often have a dark, dry surface, and [[tomentose]] caps which might easily be mistaken for Bay Boletes ''[[Boletus badius|B. badius]]''. When fully expanded, [[Pileus (mycology)|caps]] are 4 to 10 cm (1.6–4 in) in diameter with very little substance and thin flesh that turns a blue color when slightly cut or bruised.{{cite web|url=http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/id_guide/boletales/xerocomus_chrysenteron.htm |title=Xerocomus chrysenteron |accessdate=2007-12-12 |work=First Nature |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026124356/http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/id_guide/Boletales/xerocomus_chrysenteron.htm |archivedate=October 26, 2007 }} Caps mature to convex and plane in old age.{{cite web|url=http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Boletus_chrysenteron.html |title=''Xerocomus chrysenteron'' |accessdate=2007-12-12 |author=Michael Wood & Fred Stevens |date =1996–2007 |work=The Fungi of California }} Cracks in the mature cap reveal a thin layer of light red flesh below the skin. The 10 to 15 mm-diameter [[Stipe (mycology)|stems]] have no [[annulus (mycology)|ring]], are bright yellow and the lower part is covered in coral-red [[fibrils]] and has a constant elliptical to fusiform diameter throughout its length of 4 to 8 cm tall. The cream-colored stem flesh turns blue when cut. ''X. chrysenteron'' has large, yellow, angular pores,{{cite book | author = Thomas Laessoe | year = 1998 | title = Mushrooms (flexi bound) | publisher = Dorling Kindersley | isbn = 0-7513-1070-0}} and produces an olive brown [[spore print]]. Fruit bodies of ''Xerocomellus chrysenteron '' are also prone to infestation by the bolete eater (''[[Hypomyces chrysospermus]]''). ==Similarities within taxa== Macroscopic observation of ''Xerocomellus chrysenteron'' is not sufficient to determine this species with certainty, as many intermediate forms occur between it and other taxa; in particular, some forms of ''[[Boletus pruinatus|B. pruinatus]]'' and ''[[Hortiboletus rubellus]]'' are hardly distinguishable from ''B. chrysenteron'' without the aid of microscopic characters. ''[[Boletus porosporus|B. porosporus]]'' is also similar to this species, but it is easily separated on account of the whitish under layer and truncate (chopped off) spores.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtsn.tn.it/bresadola/gallery.asp?code=30&lang=eng |title=Xerocomus chrysenteron |accessdate=2007-12-12 |author=G. Bresadola |date=2005-05-02 |work=Gruppo Micologico «G. Bresadola» |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606005854/http://www.mtsn.tn.it/bresadola/gallery.asp?code=30&lang=eng |archivedate=June 6, 2011 }} Also this species is easily confused with ''[[Boletus declivitatum|B. declivitatum]]''. ==Distribution and habitat== ''Xerocomellus chrysenteron'' grows singly or in small groups in hardwood/conifer woods from early fall to mid-winter. It is [[mycorrhizal]] with hardwood trees, often [[beech]] on well drained soils. It is frequent in parts of the northern [[temperate zones]]. The species has been recorded in Taiwan. It has been [[introduced species|introduced]] to New Zealand, where it grows in groups under introduced deciduous trees.{{cite journal |author=McNabb RFR. |title=The Boletaceae of New Zealand |journal=New Zealand Journal of Botany |year=1968 |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=137–76 (see p. 148) |doi=10.1080/0028825X.1968.10429056}} {{open access}} This species may not be as common as once thought, having been often mistaken for the recently recognised [https://web.archive.org/web/20110720010628/http://www.basidiochecklist.info/DisplayResults.asp?intGBNum=42047 ''B.cisalpinus''] Simonini, Ladurner & Peintner. ==Edibility== ''Xerocomellus chrysenteron'' is considered [[edible mushroom|edible]] but not desirable due to bland flavor and soft texture.{{cite book |author=Arora D. |title=Mushrooms Demystified: A Comprehensive Guide to the Fleshy Fungi |publisher=Ten Speed Press |location=Berkeley, California |year=1986 |page=519 |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=86tM01VsFG0C&lpg=RA1-PA519&dq=Boletus%20chrysenteron&pg=RA1-PA519#v=onepage&q=Boletus%20chrysenteron&f=false}} The pores are recommended to be removed immediately after mushrooms are picked as they rapidly decay.{{cite book |author=Haas H. |title=The Young Specialist looks at Fungi |year=1969 |page=44|publisher=Burke |location=London, UK |isbn=0-222-79409-7}} Young fungi are palatable and suitable for drying, but they become slimy when cooked; mature specimens are rather tasteless and decay quickly. ==Gallery== Image:Xerocomus_chrysenteron_a1.jpg|Maturing ''Boletus chrysenteron'' Image:Bol.chrys.jpg|Showing large yellow pores File:Mold boletus chrysenteron rotfussroehrling.jpg|Mold growing on old boletus chrysenteron File:Xerocomellus chrysenteron, Edible fungi in basket 2013 G1.jpg|Picked ''Xerocomellus chrysenteron'' in basket ==See also== *[[List of North American boletes]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite journal |author=Yeh K-W, Chen Z-C. |title=The boletes of Taiwan |journal=Taiwania |year=1980 |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=166–184 |url=http://tai2.ntu.edu.tw/taiwania/pdf/tai.1980.25.166.pdf}} }} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Wikispecies|Xerocomellus chrysenteron}} *[http://www.ipet.gr/mushroom/Xerocomus_chrysenteron.html ''Xerocomus chrysenteron''] *[https://mushroomobserver.org/observer/show_name/9 About: ''Xerocomus chrysenteron'' (Bull.)
